Putin and Zelensky appear set for peace summit after fast-moving Trump talks
subhead: The US president spoke with Vladimir Putin on Monday following a 'very good' meeting with European leaders and the Ukrainian president, Donald Trump said. 'We are ready,' Volodymyr Zelensky told reporters at the White House, later saying that plans would be 'formalized in some way in the next week or 10 days.'

In Poland, thousands of young people are spending their 'vacation with the army'
subhead: Launched in 2024, this program drew about 10,000 Poles between the ages of 18 and 35 this summer who, after 27 days of training, have now become reservists in the Polish army.

headline: Hungary, an ailing economy in Europe
subhead: With prices up 50% since 2020, Hungarian consumer spending has ground to a halt. The government's gamble on an industrial revival led by Chinese battery manufacturers has yet to pay off. This situation is putting pressure on the nationalist prime minister, Viktor Orban, just months ahead of the legislative elections.

headline: In northeastern France, the third life of a synagogue, transformed into a center of contemporary art
subhead: 'Unusual Places for an Exhibition' (1/6). Le Monde explores six art centers housed in unexpected venues. Today: a former sanctuary that was blown up by the Nazis and rebuilt after the war.

headline: 'What I would give to inhabit again a country where the gravest offense the president could be accused of was sartorial misconduct'
subhead: 'Letters from America' (2/6). Writer and journalist Thomas Chatterton Williams looks back at the 'ludicrous drama' caused by Barack Obama's tan suit in 2014. The contrast with Donald Trump's gaffes is striking.

Tel Aviv's large protests are not enough to worry Netanyahu
subhead: Hundreds of thousands of people gathered on Sunday evening in solidarity with the hostages held in Gaza and to demand an end to the war in the Palestinian enclave. The Israeli prime minister's camp accused the protesters of playing into Hamas's hands.

headline: A winemaker, his daughter and a vintage for their undocumented workers
subhead: In southeastern France, Philippe Grisard and his daughter, Nad√®ge, rely daily on undocumented workers to help tend their vineyard. To draw attention to their workers' precarious legal status, they named one of their vintages 'Sans eux' ('Without Them').

headline: AI, my students and me: 'Last semester marks the nadir of my experience in academia'
subhead: 'Letters from America' (1/6). The writer and journalist Thomas Chatterton Williams has been startled by the omnipresence of artificial intelligence at university, which he believes threatens the very foundations of education and our ability to think.
